title: ABCDscores
text: computing summary scores, important understand structure nomenclature functions package: given summary score, function compute named compute_<score_name>(). example, function compute score fc_p_psb_mean named compute_fc_p_psb_mean().1 given measure/table, exists high-level compute_<table_name>_all() function computes scores measure/table. example, function compute scores fc_p_psb measure/table named compute_fc_p_psb_all(). given summary score function, certain columns—columns summarized cases additional columns like age sex—required present data score computed. function documentation lists required columns given function. addition, columns summary score function summarizes typically provided character vector named vars_<measure_name>. example, vector columns summarized fc_p_psb_mean function named vars_fc_p_psb. references page provides list available functions parameters.

title: ABCDscores
text: reading data, can start compute summary scores. example, demonstrate compute two summary scores fc_p_psb measure/table (fc_p_psb_mean fc_p_psb_nm) two different ways: using specific functions compute one score time using _all() function compute scores measure/table . refer documentation compute_fc_p_psb_mean(), see requires following variables: fc_p_psb_001, fc_p_psb_002, fc_p_psb_003. variables part dataset created downloaded DEAP, present data reading dataset.rds demonstrated . , demonstration purposes, create dummy data frame columns: summary score functions, data argument (input data frame) required, .e., can just use function like : can using fc_p_psb_nm(): can also compute scores time chaining function calls using pipe operator: Lastly, want compute scores measure one function call, can use compute_<table_name>_all() function fc_p_psb table:
code: data <- tibble::tibble(   fc_p_psb_001 = c("1", "2", "3", "4", "5"),   fc_p_psb_002 = c("1", NA, "3", "4", NA),   fc_p_psb_003 = c("1", "2", "2", "4", NA) ) data #> # A tibble: 5 × 3 #>   fc_p_psb_001 fc_p_psb_002 fc_p_psb_003 #>   <chr>        <chr>        <chr>        #> 1 1            1            1            #> 2 2            NA           2            #> 3 3            3            2            #> 4 4            4            4            #> 5 5            NA           NA compute_fc_p_psb_mean(data) #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   fc_p_psb_001 fc_p_psb_002 fc_p_psb_003 fc_p_psb_mean #>   <chr>        <chr>        <chr>                <dbl> #> 1 1            1            1                     1    #> 2 2            NA           2                    NA    #> 3 3            3            2                     2.67 #> 4 4            4            4                     4    #> 5 5            NA           NA                   NA compute_fc_p_psb_nm(data) #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   fc_p_psb_001 fc_p_psb_002 fc_p_psb_003 fc_p_psb_nm #>   <chr>        <chr>        <chr>              <int> #> 1 1            1            1                      0 #> 2 2            NA           2                      1 #> 3 3            3            2                      0 #> 4 4            4            4                      0 #> 5 5            NA           NA                     2 data |>   compute_fc_p_psb_mean() |>   compute_fc_p_psb_nm() #> # A tibble: 5 × 5 #>   fc_p_psb_001 fc_p_psb_002 fc_p_psb_003 fc_p_psb_mean fc_p_psb_nm #>   <chr>        <chr>        <chr>                <dbl>       <int> #> 1 1            1            1                     1              0 #> 2 2            NA           2                    NA              1 #> 3 3            3            2                     2.67           0 #> 4 4            4            4                     4              0 #> 5 5            NA           NA                   NA              2 compute_fc_p_psb_all(data) #> # A tibble: 5 × 5 #>   fc_p_psb_001 fc_p_psb_002 fc_p_psb_003 fc_p_psb_mean fc_p_psb_nm #>   <chr>        <chr>        <chr>                <dbl>       <int> #> 1 1            1            1                     1              0 #> 2 2            NA           2                    NA              1 #> 3 3            3            2                     2.67           0 #> 4 4            4            4                     4              0 #> 5 5            NA           NA                   NA              2

title: ABCDscores
text: max_na argument used specify maximum number missing values across summarized variables given row (participant/event) can summary score still computed. number missing values row exceeds specified value, score row set NA. Depending summary score, number missing values allowed may vary summary score functions argument. NULL: limit missing values. 0: missing values allowed. 1: one missing value allowed. … summary scores ABCD data resource, max_na set number ensures >=80% variables given score summarizes non-missing value. Users can use max_na argument want compute summary score lenient restrictive manner. example, let’s explore summary score changes set max_na argument 1 (used default, case compute_fc_p_psb_mean() 0). Now score computed second row one missing value last row two missing values: change max_na 2, score also computed last row:
code: compute_fc_p_psb_mean(data, max_na = 1) #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   fc_p_psb_001 fc_p_psb_002 fc_p_psb_003 fc_p_psb_mean #>   <chr>        <chr>        <chr>                <dbl> #> 1 1            1            1                     1    #> 2 2            NA           2                     2    #> 3 3            3            2                     2.67 #> 4 4            4            4                     4    #> 5 5            NA           NA                   NA compute_fc_p_psb_mean(data, max_na = 2) #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   fc_p_psb_001 fc_p_psb_002 fc_p_psb_003 fc_p_psb_mean #>   <chr>        <chr>        <chr>                <dbl> #> 1 1            1            1                     1    #> 2 2            NA           2                     2    #> 3 3            3            2                     2.67 #> 4 4            4            4                     4    #> 5 5            NA           NA                    5

title: ABCDscores
text: exclude argument used specify values excluded computation score. specific values data might considered missing values, e.g., coded non-responses like “Don’t know” (999), “Decline answer” (777), etc. argument allows user specify values treated missing values computation score (importantly, max_na argument applies values either missing, NA, specified values excluded using exclude argument). score functions argument. example use another score function compute_mh_p_abcl__afs__frnd_sum exclude argument. first construct dummy data frame: compute score, 1, 4 rows computed, rows contain 777 999 NA values. can also exclude custom values, example, can exclude 4, first row computed.
code: data <- tibble::tibble(   mh_p_abcl__frnd_001 = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5),   mh_p_abcl__frnd_002 = c(1, 777, 3, 4, 777),   mh_p_abcl__frnd_003 = c(1, 2, NA, 4, 777),   mh_p_abcl__frnd_004 = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 999), ) data #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   mh_p_abcl__frnd_001 mh_p_abcl__frnd_002 mh_p_abcl__frnd_003 #>                 <dbl>               <dbl>               <dbl> #> 1                   1                   1                   1 #> 2                   2                 777                   2 #> 3                   3                   3                  NA #> 4                   4                   4                   4 #> 5                   5                 777                 777 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: mh_p_abcl__frnd_004 <dbl> compute_mh_p_abcl__afs__frnd_sum(data, exclude = c("777", "999")) #> # A tibble: 5 × 5 #>   mh_p_abcl__frnd_001 mh_p_abcl__frnd_002 mh_p_abcl__frnd_003 #>                 <dbl>               <dbl>               <dbl> #> 1                   1                   1                   1 #> 2                   2                 777                   2 #> 3                   3                   3                  NA #> 4                   4                   4                   4 #> 5                   5                 777                 777 #> # ℹ 2 more variables: mh_p_abcl__frnd_004 <dbl>, mh_p_abcl__afs__frnd_sum <int> compute_mh_p_abcl__afs__frnd_sum(data, exclude = c("777", "999", "4")) #> # A tibble: 5 × 5 #>   mh_p_abcl__frnd_001 mh_p_abcl__frnd_002 mh_p_abcl__frnd_003 #>                 <dbl>               <dbl>               <dbl> #> 1                   1                   1                   1 #> 2                   2                 777                   2 #> 3                   3                   3                  NA #> 4                   4                   4                   4 #> 5                   5                 777                 777 #> # ℹ 2 more variables: mh_p_abcl__frnd_004 <dbl>, mh_p_abcl__afs__frnd_sum <int>

title: Achenbach System of Empirically Based Assessment (ASEBA) T-scores
text: Achenbach System Empirically Based Assessment, ASEBA (Achenbach, 2017; Achenbach, 2019), widely used, evidence-based tool designed assess behavioral, emotional, social, adaptive functioning individuals aged 1½ 90+ years. Developed Thomas Achenbach response limitations early psychiatric classifications like DSM-, employs multi-informant approach capture behavioral patterns across different settings (e.g., home, school) perspectives (e.g., parents, teachers, self-reports).

title: Achenbach System of Empirically Based Assessment (ASEBA) T-scores
text: T-scores standardized scores indicate individual’s performance compares age sex matched normative sample. scores derived converting raw scores standardized format mean 50 standard deviation 10. establish norms, ASEBA collected data large, representative samples across various societies, taking account factors age, sex, cultural background. extensive normative data allows comparison individual’s scores relevant peer group, facilitating identification behavioral, emotional, social, thought problems (Achenbach, 2019).

title: Achenbach System of Empirically Based Assessment (ASEBA) T-scores
text: ABCD Study® uses six ASEBA forms: Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL) Adult Behavior Checklist (ABCL) Youth Self-Report (YSR) Adult Self-Report (ASR) Brief Problem Monitor (BPM; Youth) Brief Problem Monitor (BPM; Teacher) Note: 6.0 release, T-scores computed ASR form (raw scores available tabulated data). may change future releases.

title: Achenbach System of Empirically Based Assessment (ASEBA) T-scores
text: calculate T-scores ASEBA forms, one must obtain norming tables. Since tables proprietary product licensed ASEBA, included ABCDscores package. Therefore, demonstrate compute T-scores using simulated norming table. use code real-world setting, need obtain norming tables ASEBA.

title: Achenbach System of Empirically Based Assessment (ASEBA) T-scores
text: ASEBA norm table needs organized dataframe following columns: sex: character, either "1" male "2" female. age_min: numeric, minimum age norm group. age_max: numeric, maximum age norm group. scale_r: numeric, raw score. scale_t: numeric, T-score. example simulated norming table:
code: data_norm <- tibble::tibble(   sex = c("1", "1", "1", "1", "1"),   age_min = 18,   age_max = 35,   scale_r = 0:4,   scale_t = 20:24 ) data_norm #> # A tibble: 5 × 5 #>   sex   age_min age_max scale_r scale_t #>   <chr>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <int>   <int> #> 1 1          18      35       0      20 #> 2 1          18      35       1      21 #> 3 1          18      35       2      22 #> 4 1          18      35       3      23 #> 5 1          18      35       4      24

title: Achenbach System of Empirically Based Assessment (ASEBA) T-scores
text: compute T-scores, can use compute_<score_name>() functions. input output important arguments functions similar score functions ABCDscores package. Please refer Get started page overview use functions. T-score functions following additional arguments: data_norm: tibble, norming table (one generated ). col_age: character, specifies column name input data contains age participants. required match age participant age range norming table. example, score mh_p_abcl__afs__frnd_tscore, default value col_age "mh_p_abcl__cg2__age_001". Please refer reference pages see default value col_age given score. col_sex: character, specifies column name input data contains participants’ age. Similarly, information required look respective T-score. example, score mh_p_abcl__afs__frnd_tscore, default value col_sex "mh_p_abcl__cg2_gi". Please refer reference pages see default value col_sex given score. data preparation, please also refer Get started page. creating dataset containing needed columns, downloading , reading data frame, data ready T-score computation. example, assuming data frame containing needed columns called data norming table called data_norm, can execute compute T-score mh_p_abcl__afs__frnd_tscore ABCL.

title: Achenbach System of Empirically Based Assessment (ASEBA) T-scores
text: provide actual norming tables part package, run code . demonstrate compute T-scores using simulated norming table simulated data table using lower level function ss_tscore(). specific compute...() T-score functions use lower level function ss_tscore(). difference scale-specific T-score functions default values, col_age col_sex. Create simulated data table: Compute T-scores using simulated norm data tables: ss_tscore() find match norming table, return NA T-score. example, example, scores following rows NA: row 4: age 99, age range [18, 35]. row 5: raw score 5, makes raw score sum 7, raw score range [0, 4]. row 6: sex “2”, included simulated norming table.
code: data <- tibble::tibble(   var1 = c(0, 1, NA, 1, 2, 3),   var2 = c(1, 2, 1, 2, 5, 3),   age = c(18, 20, 25, 99, 35, 30),   sex = c("1", "1", "1", "1", "1", "2") ) data #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #>    var1  var2   age sex   #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> #> 1     0     1    18 1     #> 2     1     2    20 1     #> 3    NA     1    25 1     #> 4     1     2    99 1     #> 5     2     5    35 1     #> 6     3     3    30 2 ss_tscore(   data = data,   data_norm = data_norm,   col_age = "age", # specify the age column   col_sex = "sex", # specify the sex column   vars = c("var1", "var2") # specify individual items summarized in the score ) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>    var1  var2   age sex   tscore #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <int> #> 1     0     1    18 1         21 #> 2     1     2    20 1         23 #> 3    NA     1    25 1         21 #> 4     1     2    99 1         NA #> 5     2     5    35 1         NA #> 6     3     3    30 2         NA

title: Achenbach System of Empirically Based Assessment (ASEBA) T-scores
text: can use max_na exclude arguments modify certain aspects T-score computation. max_na argument specifies maximum number missing values allowed still compute T-score. example, can set max_na = 0 allow missing values summarized items (default ss_tscore() NULL, .e., limit, specific functions ASEBA T-scores impose limit). rerun code change, NA returned row 3 var1 NA row. exclude argument excludes certain values, .e, converts NA score computation. example, can set exclude = "0" exclude "0" values computation. rerun code change, NA returned row 1 var1 "0" row.
code: ss_tscore(   data = data,   data_norm = data_norm,   col_age = "age",   col_sex = "sex",   vars = c("var1", "var2"),   max_na = 0 # specify maximum number of missing values ) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>    var1  var2   age sex   tscore #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <int> #> 1     0     1    18 1         21 #> 2     1     2    20 1         23 #> 3    NA     1    25 1         NA #> 4     1     2    99 1         NA #> 5     2     5    35 1         NA #> 6     3     3    30 2         NA ss_tscore(   data = data,   data_norm = data_norm,   col_age = "age",   col_sex = "sex",   vars = c("var1", "var2"),   max_na = 0,   exclude = c("0") # specify values to exclude from the computation ) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>    var1  var2   age sex   tscore #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <int> #> 1     0     1    18 1         NA #> 2     1     2    20 1         23 #> 3    NA     1    25 1         NA #> 4     1     2    99 1         NA #> 5     2     5    35 1         NA #> 6     3     3    30 2         NA

title: Substance Use Interview (SUI) summary scores
text: Substance Use Interview (SUI) survey used collect background information participant’s substance use since last visit. Additionally, survey gathers follow-information use context, first use date, details. Scientifically, survey allows us understand initiation patterns substance use participants. information provided SUI also used decide whether Timeline Followback interview done given participant access substance use detail.

title: Substance Use Interview (SUI) summary scores
text: developed three basic functions can used compute SUI summary scores relevant substances changing value substance function parameter: compute_su_y_sui__onset_useage(): Computes age use onset given substance. compute_su_y_sui__reg_useage(): Compute age regular use given substance. compute_su_y_sui__last__day_count(): Counts days since last use given substance.

title: Substance Use Interview (SUI) summary scores
text: SUI item-level data available authorized users NBDC Data Hub part tabulated data resource. Please refer Get started page general information assemble download dataset. computation SUI summary scores, please note following requirements: compute_su_y_sui__onset_useage() compute_su_y_sui__reg_useage() require ab_g_stc__cohort_dob column. compute_su_y_sui__last__day_count() requires ab_g_dyn__visit_dtt column.

title: Timeline Followback (TLFB) summary scores
text: Timeline Followback (TLFB) (Sobell, 1996) semi-structured interview method used assess specific quantified estimates substance use specified period, approxiamtely past 12 months ABCD. involves participants recalling substance use guided Research Assistant (RA). RA fills TLFB calendar, documenting reports substance use helping participants ground responses specific dates events, ensuring accurate reporting substance use patterns.

title: Timeline Followback (TLFB) summary scores
text: TLFB raw data available authorized users NBDC Data Hub. combines information logfiles old new versions TLFB application used ABCD assessments (additional information, please see documentation webpage). raw data long-form data frame one row per reported substance use instance following structure: TLFB interview records usage following substances: “‘Fake’ Marijuana Synthetics” “Alcohol” “Anabolic Steroids” “Drug Used Get High” “Blunts Combined Tobacco Marijuana Joints” “CBD (Non-Medical Use)” “Cathinones Bath Salts, Drone, Meph” “Cigars, Little Cigars, Cigarillos” “Cocaine Crack Cocaine” “Concentrated Marijuana Tinctures” “Ecstasy, Molly, MDMA” “Electronic Nicotine Vaping Products” “GHB, Liquid G, Georgia Homeboy” “Hallucinogen Drugs including LSD, PCP, Peyote, Mescaline, DMT, AMT, Foxy” “Heroin, Opium, Junk, Smack, Dope” “Hookah Tobacco” “Inhalants” “Ketamine Special K” “Marijuana Edibles” “Marijuana Infused Alcohol Drinks” “Methamphetamine, Meth, Crystal Meth” “Nicotine Replacements” “OTC Cough Cold Medicine, DXM, ‘Lean’, ‘Purple Drank’” “Prescription Anxiolytics, Tranquilizers, Sedatives” “Prescription Pain Relievers Opioids” “Prescription Stimulants” “Psilocybin, Magic Mushrooms, Shrooms” “Salvia” “Smokeless Tobacco, Chew, Snus” “Smoking Marijuana Flower” “Smoking Marijuana Oils Concentrates” “Tobacco Cigarette” “Tobacco Pipe” “Vaped Marijuana Flower” “Vaped Marijuana Oils Concentrates” “Marijuana (forms)” “Nicotine (forms)” “Marijuana (forms)” “Nicotine (forms)” aggregating different methods consumption.

title: Timeline Followback (TLFB) summary scores
text: ABCD Study’s tabulated data resource includes summary scores TLFB interview. summary scores domains typically define one function per summary score, TLFB summary scores computed using set basic functions, user-defined parameters. allows flexible modular approach computing TLFB summary scores, e.g., computing score different substances time periods. section describes basic functions use compute ABCD summary scores using ABCDscores R package. also describes users can use functions compute TLFB summary scores reported ABCD data. basic functions : compute_tlfb_abst(): Compute abstinence substance use days. compute_tlfb_dt(): Compute first/last day substance use. compute_tlfb_maxdose(): Compute maximum dose substance use. compute_tlfb_mean(): Compute mean dose substance use. compute_tlfb_totdose(): Compute total dose substance use. compute_tlfb_ud(): Compute number substance use days. functions take following parameters: substance One several substance(s) compute score . period: period (detailed, estimated, ) score computed . days: Number days TLFB interview consider. wknd: Whether score computed weekends days, week days, days co_use: computes score days substance taken specified substance(s). binge: Allows specify binge thresholds apply, either general sex. position: Whether consider first last substance use parameters used functions parameters mutally exclusive (see function documentation details). following gives overview function can use parameter:

title: Timeline Followback (TLFB) summary scores
text: following table gives overview basic functions used compute 905 summary scores reported ABCD data resource (can use filter boxes top columns filter table): Note function calls expect TLFB raw data read data frame data_tlfb global environment. example, compute summary scores, one run:
code: # read raw data data_tlfb <- arrow::read_parquet("tlfb_raw.parquet")  # compute summary score `su_y_tlfb__alc__1mo__wknd_totdose` compute_tlfb_totdose(   data = data_tlfb,   name = "su_y_tlfb__alc__1mo__wknd_totdose",   substance = "Alcohol",   period = NULL,   days = 30,   wknd = TRUE,   co_use = NULL,   binge = NULL )  # compute summary score `su_y_tlfb__alc__1mo__wknd_ud` compute_tlfb_ud(   data = data_tlfb,   name = "su_y_tlfb__alc__1mo__wknd_ud",   substance = "Alcohol",   period = NULL,   days = 30,   wknd = TRUE,   co_use = NULL,   binge = NULL )  # compute all summary scores in the ABCD data resource data_tlfb_ss <- purrr::map(   tlfb_config$call,   ~ eval(parse(text = .x)) ) |>   purrr::reduce(     full_join,     by = join_by(       participant_id,       session_id     )   )

code: #' Add age of use #' #' @description #' Adds an `age_use` column to the TLFB raw data based on the anonymized date of #' birth and the date of use. Age is computed in years (with decimals) using #' an exact method taking into account leap years (using functions from the #' `lubridate` package). #' #' @param data tibble. The TLFB raw data. #' @param data_dob tibble. A data frame containing at least two columns, the #'   participant ID and the anonymized date of birth. #' @param col_dob character. The name of the column in `data_dob` that has the #'   anonymized date of birth. #' #' @return tibble. The TLFB raw data with an additional column `age_use`. add_age_use <- function(data, data_dob, col_dob) {   data_dob <- data_dob |>     select(       participant_id,       dob = {{ col_dob }}     )    data |>     left_join(       data_dob,       by = "participant_id"     ) |>     mutate(       age_use = lubridate::interval(dob, dt_use) / lubridate::years(1)     ) |>     select(       -dob     ) }  # expects that a data frame `data_dob` with a column `dob_anonymized` # to be available in the global environment; uses the `add_age_use()` function # to add a column with the age of the participant at each reported use and # finds the first use of marijuana for each participant data_tlfb |>   compute_tlfb_dt(     name      = "dt_use",     substance = "Marijuana (all forms)",     period    = "detailed",     position  = "first"   ) |>   summarize(     dt_use = min(dt_use),     .by = participant_id   ) |>   add_age_use(data_dob, "dob_anonymized") |>   select(     participant_id,     mj_age_first_use_tlfb = age_use   ) #' Add week sequence #' #' @description #' Adds a `wk_seq` column to the TLFB raw data. The week sequence is computed #' based on the minimum and maximum dates of use in the data, with week 1 being #' the one that contains the minimum date of use and the maximum week number #' being the one that contains the maximum date of use. That is, the week #' sequence contains consecutive week numbers from the earliest to the latest #' possible date and works across all years contained in the data. Joining this #' week sequence to the data allows for the computation of weekly summaries and #' streaks of consecutive use weeks. #' #' @details #' The week sequence can be computed using either the `lubridate::isoweek()` or #' the `lubridate::epiweek()` command. The `lubridate::isoweek()` command uses #' the European standard for week numbering, where Monday is the first day and #' Sunday is the last day of the week. The `lubridate::epiweek()`command uses #' the US standard where Sunday is the first day of the week and Saturday is the #' last day. The default is to use the `lubridate::isoweek()` command as it does #' not break up a weekend into two different weeks. #' #' @param data tibble. The TLFB raw data. #' @param standard character. The standard to use for week numbering. One of #'   `"iso"` or `"epi"` (Default: `"iso"`; see details). #' #' @return tibble. The TLFB raw data with an additional column `wk_seq`. add_wk_seq <- function(data, standard = c("iso", "epi")) {   standard <- match.arg(standard)    week_command <- switch(standard,     iso = lubridate::isoweek,     epi = lubridate::epiweek   )    data_weeks <- tibble(     dt = seq(       min(data$dt_use),       max(data$dt_use),       by = 1     )   ) |>     mutate(       yr_use = lubridate::year(dt),       wk_use = week_command(dt)     ) |>     distinct(       yr_use,       wk_use     ) |>     arrange(       yr_use,       wk_use     ) |>     mutate(       wk_seq = row_number()     )    data |>     mutate(       yr_use = lubridate::year(dt_use),       wk_use = week_command(dt_use)     ) |>     left_join(       data_weeks,       by = join_by(yr_use, wk_use)     ) |>     select(       -yr_use,       -wk_use     ) }  data_tlfb |>   ABCDscores::filter_tlfb(     substance = "Alcohol",     binge = list("M" = 5, "F" = 4),     period = "detailed"   ) |>   add_wk_seq(standard = "iso") |>   summarize(     alc_binge = n_distinct(dt_use),     .by = c(participant_id, session_id, wk_seq)   ) |>   arrange(     participant_id,     session_id,     wk_seq   ) |>   mutate(     streak = cumsum(c(TRUE, diff(wk_seq) != 1)),     .by = c(participant_id, session_id)   ) |>   mutate(     n_wks = row_number(),     .by = c(participant_id, session_id, streak)   ) |>   summarize(     alc_wks_binge = max(n_wks),     .by = c(participant_id)   ) |>   arrange(     desc(alc_wks_binge)   )

title: Check arguments for TLFB summary score functions — check_args_tlfb
text: data tibble. data frame containing TLFB raw data. name character. name output column computed score. substance character (vector). substance(s) compute score . Must one several following values: "'Fake' Marijuana Synthetics" "Alcohol" "Anabolic Steroids" "Drug Used Get High" "Blunts Combined Tobacco Marijuana Joints" "CBD (Non-Medical Use)" "Cathinones Bath Salts, Drone, Meph" "Cigars, Little Cigars, Cigarillos" "Cocaine Crack Cocaine" "Concentrated Marijuana Tinctures" "Ecstasy, Molly, MDMA" "Electronic Nicotine Vaping Products" "GHB, Liquid G, Georgia Homeboy" "Hallucinogen Drugs including LSD, PCP, Peyote, Mescaline, DMT, AMT, Foxy" "Heroin, Opium, Junk, Smack, Dope" "Hookah Tobacco" "Inhalants" "Ketamine Special K" "Marijuana Edibles" "Marijuana Infused Alcohol Drinks" "Methamphetamine, Meth, Crystal Meth" "Nicotine Replacements" "OTC Cough Cold Medicine, DXM, 'Lean', 'Purple Drank'" "Prescription Anxiolytics, Tranquilizers, Sedatives" "Prescription Pain Relievers Opioids" "Prescription Stimulants" "Psilocybin, Magic Mushrooms, Shrooms" "Salvia" "Smokeless Tobacco, Chew, Snus" "Smoking Marijuana Flower" "Smoking Marijuana Oils Concentrates" "Tobacco Cigarette" "Tobacco Pipe" "Vaped Marijuana Flower" "Vaped Marijuana Oils Concentrates" "Marijuana (forms)" "Nicotine (forms)" (Default: NULL, .e., substances considered.) period character (vector). period score computed . Must one "detailed" (last year date TLFB interview) "estimated" (one year date TLFB). (Default: NULL, .e., periods considered). used combination days. days integer. Number days TLFB interview consider. (Default: NULL, .e., days considered). used combination period. wknd logical. Whether score computed weekends (TRUE) week days (FALSE). (Default: NULL, .e., days considered). co_use character (vector). Co-use substance(s). Must one several possible values substance listed . days specified substance(s) /used together (one ) co-use substance(s) considered. (Default: NULL, .e., co-use considered). co_use specified without substance can contain substance(s) specified substance. binge (named list ) numeric. Binge threshold(s) substance(s). one value provided, used, independent sex participant. list provided, must contain two named elements: "F" (female) "M" (male) respective sex-specific binge thresholds. days quantity substance(s) exceeds specified threshold(s) considered. (Default: NULL, .e., binge behavior considered). position character. position substance use event. Must one "first" "last". (Default: NULL, .e., position considered).

Must one "detailed" (last year date TLFB interview) "estimated" (one year date TLFB). (Default: NULL, .e., periods considered). used combination days. days integer. Number days TLFB interview consider. (Default: NULL, .e., days considered). used combination period. binge (named list ) numeric. Binge threshold(s) substance(s). one value provided, used, independent sex participant. list provided, must contain two named elements: "F" (female) "M" (male) respective sex-specific binge thresholds. days quantity substance(s) exceeds specified threshold(s) considered. code: ss_count(   data,   name,   vars,   vars_temp = NULL,   exclude = NULL,   combine = FALSE,   allow_missingness = TRUE,   cond )

title: Compute the number or count of matching conditions — ss_count
text: data tbl. Data frame containing columns summarized. name character. name summary score. vars character vector. name(s) column(s) summarized. vars_temp character vector. name(s) temporary column(s) used compute summary score. Note, columns checked missingness. See allow_missingness. exclude character (vector). value(s) excluded (Default: NULL; values used). combine logical. Whether combine summary score column input data frame (Default: FALSE). allow_missingness logical. Default set TRUE. TRUE, summary score set NA -going fields missingness. FALSE, summary score set NA -going fields missingness. NOTE: exclude operation performed prior checking missingness. cond character vector. specified condition, involving values specific input fields, gets tested 1 (TRUE) 0 (FALSE). condition specified "field_name", numeric value field counted greater 1. Whereas conditions met can get value 1 0. summary score sum values obtained testing condition specified cond.

title: Compute the number or count of matching conditions — ss_count
text: tbl. input data frame summary score appended new column.

title: Compute the number or count of matching conditions — ss_count
code: dat <- tibble::tibble(   id   = c("1", "2", "3", "4", "5", "6", "7", "8"),   a_1  = c(1, 1, NA, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1),   a_2  = c(1, NA, NA, 1, 1, NA, 1, 1),   b_1  = c(1, 1, NA, NA, 1, 1, 1, 1),   b_2  = c(1, 1, NA, 1, 1, NA, 1, 1),   c    = c(NA, 1, NA, 1, 777, 0, 1, 0) )  # define conditions to assess conditions <- c(   "a_1 == 1 & a_2 == 1",   "b_1 == 1 & b_2 == 1",   "c" )  # count number of matched conditions ss_count(   data    = dat,   name    = "ss",   vars    = c("a_1", "a_2", "b_1", "b_2", "c"),   cond    = conditions,   combine = TRUE ) #> # A tibble: 8 × 7 #>   id      a_1   a_2   b_1   b_2     c    ss #>   <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <int> #> 1 1         1     1     1     1    NA     2 #> 2 2         1    NA     1     1     1     2 #> 3 3        NA    NA    NA    NA    NA    NA #> 4 4         1     1    NA     1     1     2 #> 5 5         1     1     1     1   777   779 #> 6 6         1    NA     1    NA     0     0 #> 7 7         1     1     1     1     1     3 #> 8 8         1     1     1     1     0     2  ss_count(   data    = dat,   name    = "ss",   vars    = c("a_1", "a_2", "b_1", "b_2", "c"),   cond    = conditions,   exclude = c("777"),   combine = TRUE ) #> # A tibble: 8 × 7 #>   id      a_1   a_2   b_1   b_2     c    ss #>   <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <int> #> 1 1         1     1     1     1    NA     2 #> 2 2         1    NA     1     1     1     2 #> 3 3        NA    NA    NA    NA    NA    NA #> 4 4         1     1    NA     1     1     2 #> 5 5         1     1     1     1   777     2 #> 6 6         1    NA     1    NA     0     0 #> 7 7         1     1     1     1     1     3 #> 8 8         1     1     1     1     0     2  conditions <- paste(   c(     "a_1 == 1 & a_2 == 1",     "b_1 == 1 & b_2 == 1",     "c >= 1"   ),   collapse = "&" )  ss_count(   data    = dat,   name    = "ss",   vars    = c("a_1", "a_2", "b_1", "b_2", "c"),   cond    = conditions,   exclude = c("777"),   combine = TRUE ) #> # A tibble: 8 × 7 #>   id      a_1   a_2   b_1   b_2     c    ss #>   <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <int> #> 1 1         1     1     1     1    NA     0 #> 2 2         1    NA     1     1     1     0 #> 3 3        NA    NA    NA    NA    NA    NA #> 4 4         1     1    NA     1     1     0 #> 5 5         1     1     1     1   777     0 #> 6 6         1    NA     1    NA     0     0 #> 7 7         1     1     1     1     1     1 #> 8 8         1     1     1     1     0     0  ss_count(   data = dat,   name = "ss",   vars = c("a_1", "a_2", "b_1", "b_2", "c"),   cond = conditions,   exclude = c("777"),   allow_missingness = FALSE,   combine = TRUE ) #> # A tibble: 8 × 7 #>   id      a_1   a_2   b_1   b_2     c    ss #>   <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <int> #> 1 1         1     1     1     1    NA    NA #> 2 2         1    NA     1     1     1    NA #> 3 3        NA    NA    NA    NA    NA    NA #> 4 4         1     1    NA     1     1    NA #> 5 5         1     1     1     1   777    NA #> 6 6         1    NA     1    NA     0    NA #> 7 7         1     1     1     1     1     1 #> 8 8         1     1     1     1     0     0

A tibble: 7 × 1 #>   score_prorated_sum #>                <int> #> 1                  5 #> 2                 10 #> 3                 15 #> 4                 NA #> 5                 NA #> 6                 NA #> 7                 NA  data |>   ss_prsum(     name = "score_prorated_sum",     vars = c("a", "b", "c", "d", "e"),     max_na = NULL,     exclude = NULL,     events = c("ses-00A", "ses-01A"),   ) #> # A tibble: 7 × 8 #>   participant_id session_id     a     b     c     d     e score_prorated_sum #>   <chr>          <chr>      <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>              <int> #> 1 A              ses-00A        1     1     1     1    NA                  5 #> 2 A              ses-01A        2   777     2     2     2                785 #> 3 A              ses-02A        3     3   999     3     3                 NA #> 4 B              ses-02A        4     4     4   777    NA                 NA #> 5 A              ses-03A        5    NA   777   999     5                 NA #> 6 B              0ses-3A       NA    NA    NA    NA    NA                 NA #> 7 A              ses-04A        1    NA    NA    NA    NA                 NA

title: Compute sum — ss_sum
text: Computes sum set variables, option exclude certain values (non-responses like "know"/"Decline answer") set maximum number missing values.

title: Compute sum — ss_sum
code: ss_sum(   data,   name,   vars,   max_na = NULL,   exclude = NULL,   events = NULL,   as_integer = TRUE,   combine = TRUE )

title: Compute sum — ss_sum
text: data tbl. Data frame containing columns summarized. name character. name summary score. vars character vector. names columns summarized. max_na numeric, positive whole number. Number missing items allowed (Default: NULL; restriction missing values). exclude character (vector). value(s) excluded (Default: NULL; values used). events character (vector). compute summary score specified events (Default: NULL; computed events). as_integer logical. Whether coerce summary score integer, default TRUE. FALSE, summary score double. combine logical. Whether combine summary score column input data frame (Default: TRUE).

title: Compute sum — ss_sum
text: tbl. input data frame summary score appended new column.

title: Compute sum — ss_sum
code: data <- tibble::tribble(   ~session_id, ~a, ~b,  ~c,  ~d,  ~e,   "ses-00A",   1,  1,   1,   1,   NA,   "ses-01A",   2,  777, 2,   2,   2,   "ses-02A",   3,  3,   999, 3,   3,   "ses-02A",   4,  4,   4,   777, NA,   "ses-03A",   5,  NA,  777, 999, 5,   "ses-03A",   NA, NA,  NA,  NA,  NA,   "ses-04A",   1,  NA,  NA,  NA,  NA )  data |>   ss_sum(     name = "mean",     vars = c("a", "b", "c", "d", "e"),     max_na = 1,     exclude = c("777", "999")   ) #> # A tibble: 7 × 7 #>   session_id     a     b     c     d     e  mean #>   <chr>      <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <int> #> 1 ses-00A        1     1     1     1    NA     4 #> 2 ses-01A        2   777     2     2     2     8 #> 3 ses-02A        3     3   999     3     3    12 #> 4 ses-02A        4     4     4   777    NA    NA #> 5 ses-03A        5    NA   777   999     5    NA #> 6 ses-03A       NA    NA    NA    NA    NA    NA #> 7 ses-04A        1    NA    NA    NA    NA    NA  data |>   ss_sum(     name = "mean",     vars = c("a", "b", "c", "d", "e"),     max_na = 1,     exclude = c("777", "999"),     combine = FALSE   ) #> # A tibble: 7 × 1 #>    mean #>   <int> #> 1     4 #> 2     8 #> 3    12 #> 4    NA #> 5    NA #> 6    NA #> 7    NA  data |>   ss_sum(     name = "mean",     vars = c("a", "b", "c", "d", "e"),     max_na = NULL,     exclude = NULL,     events = c("ses-00A", "ses-01A"),   ) #> # A tibble: 7 × 7 #>   session_id     a     b     c     d     e  mean #>   <chr>      <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <int> #> 1 ses-00A        1     1     1     1    NA     4 #> 2 ses-01A        2   777     2     2     2   785 #> 3 ses-02A        3     3   999     3     3    NA #> 4 ses-02A        4     4     4   777    NA    NA #> 5 ses-03A        5    NA   777   999     5    NA #> 6 ses-03A       NA    NA    NA    NA    NA    NA #> 7 ses-04A        1    NA    NA    NA    NA    NA

what: Compute sum for MH-PLE scores — ss_sum_mh_ple
title: Compute sum for MH-PLE scores — ss_sum_mh_ple
text: Calculates sum scores variables forking logic, variables may applicable based certain conditions. Missing values exclusions handled based forking variable values.

title: Compute sum for MH-PLE scores — ss_sum_mh_ple
code: ss_sum_mh_ple(   data,   name,   fork_vars,   fork_val = "1",   vars,   max_na = NULL,   exclude = NULL,   events = NULL,   combine = TRUE,   no_na = FALSE )

title: Compute sum for MH-PLE scores — ss_sum_mh_ple
text: data Data frame containing columns summarize name String specifying name summary score column fork_vars Character vector columns used logical conditions fork_val String indicating value fork_vars valid responses vars Character vector columns summarize max_na Integer maximum allowed missing values exclude Character vector values exclude events Character vector events compute scores combine Logical; TRUE, append score input data no_na Logical; TRUE, return NA value missing

title: Compute sum for MH-PLE scores — ss_sum_mh_ple
text: Data frame summary score column

title: Compute sum for MH-PLE scores — ss_sum_mh_ple
code: data <- tibble::tribble(   ~session_id, ~a, ~b, ~c, ~a__severe, ~b__severe, ~c__severe,   "ses-00A", "1", "1", "1", "1", NA, NA,   "ses-01A", "1", "1", "1", "2", "777", "2" )  data |>   ss_sum_mh_ple(     name = "sum",     fork_vars = c("a", "b", "c"),     vars = paste0(c("a", "b", "c"), "__severe"),     max_na = 1,     exclude = c("777", "999")   ) #> # A tibble: 2 × 8 #>   session_id a     b     c     a__severe b__severe c__severe   sum #>   <chr>      <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr>     <chr>     <chr>     <int> #> 1 ses-00A    1     1     1     1         NA        NA           NA #> 2 ses-01A    1     1     1     2         777       2             4

title: Compute T-score — ss_tscore
text: function computes T-score based given columns, provided T-score table.

title: Compute T-score — ss_tscore
code: ss_tscore(   data,   data_norm = NULL,   vars,   name = "tscore",   max_na = NULL,   exclude = NULL,   col_age = "age",   col_sex = "sex",   combine = TRUE )

title: Compute T-score — ss_tscore
text: data tbl. Data frame containing columns summarized. data_norm tbl. Data frame containing T-score table. See details. vars character vector. names columns summarized. name character. column name T-score. max_na numeric, positive whole number. Number missing items allowed (Default: NULL; restriction missing values). exclude character (vector). value(s) excluded (Default: NULL; values used). col_age character. name age column. col_sex character name sex column. combine logical. Whether combine summary score column input data frame (Default: TRUE).

title: Compute T-score — ss_tscore
text: tbl. input data frame T-score appended new column combine TRUE, otherwise T-score column.

title: Compute T-score — ss_tscore
text: data_norm data frame containing T-score table. default value NULL used internal usage (see ). normal usage, data_norm provided. table following columns: sex: character factor ok. biological sex participant. values either "1" (male) "2" (female). age_min: numeric. minimum age participant. age_max: numeric. maximum age participant. scale_r: numeric. raw score scale. scale_t: numeric. T-score scale. example
code: A tibble: xxx  5 sex   age_min age_max scale_r scale_t <chr>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>  1       18      35    50        1  1       18      35    50.5      2  1       18      35    51        3  1       18      35    51.5      4 ...

title: Compute T-score — ss_tscore
text: age participant range T-score table, function return NA. raw score range T-score table, function return NA.  sex column "1" "2", function return NA. required columns NA, row return NA.

title: Compute T-score — ss_tscore
text: used DSM internally, data_norm can omitted. Instead, function try find T-score table list_tscore option, tries find tscore list based object name provided list_tscore option. object found, function automatically extract T-score table based function name. list_tscore object present global environment. See get_tscore_tbl() details construct list_tscore. example

title: Compute T-score — ss_tscore
code: data_norm <- tibble::tibble(   sex = c("1", "1", "1", "1", "1"),   age_min = 18,   age_max = 35,   scale_r = 0:4,   scale_t = 20:24 ) data <- tibble::tibble(   var1 = c(0, 1, NA, 1, 2),   var2 = c(1, 2, 1, 2, 5),   age = c(18, 20, 25, 99, 35),   sex = c("1", "1", "1", "1", "1") ) ss_tscore(   data = data,   data_norm = data_norm,   max_na = 0,   vars = c("var1", "var2") ) #> # A tibble: 5 × 5 #>    var1  var2   age sex   tscore #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <int> #> 1     0     1    18 1         21 #> 2     1     2    20 1         23 #> 3    NA     1    25 1         NA #> 4     1     2    99 1         NA #> 5     2     5    35 1         NA
